description:
Tympanuchus pallidicinctus, commonly known as the Lesser Prairie-Chicken, is a species of grouse native to the southern Great Plains region of the United States. This medium-sized bird is characterized by its distinctive mottled brown and white plumage, with a distinctive pale-colored neck ruff or "bib" from which it derives its species name.

The Lesser Prairie-Chicken is known for its unique courtship displays, where males gather on communal breeding grounds called "leks" and perform elaborate visual and vocal displays to attract females. These displays involve inflating their air sacs, spreading their tail feathers, and producing distinctive "whooping" and "popping" vocalizations.

Habitat preferences for the Lesser Prairie-Chicken include open, semi-arid grasslands and shrublands, often with a mix of native grasses, forbs, and scattered low-growing shrubs. The species is adapted to the harsh, drought-prone conditions of its native range, which includes parts of Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Colorado, and Kansas.

Due to habitat loss, fragmentation, and other environmental pressures, the Lesser Prairie-Chicken is considered a threatened species, with conservation efforts focused on preserving and restoring its remaining populations and habitats across the southern Great Plains.
